II. 

RATIONALE: SECTOR PERFORMANCE, PROBLEMS, AND OPPORTUNITIES 

Performance Indicators and Analysis 

 
2. 
The  Water  Resources  Management  Sector  Project  was  prepared  by  a  project 
preparatory  technical  assistance  (PPTA)  approved  in  2008.1  This  document  is  based  on  the 
consultants’  studies,  surveys,  and  reports;  the  findings  of  Asian  Development  Bank  (ADB) 
missions;  and  discussion  with  government  agencies,  stakeholders,  beneficiaries,  and 
development  partners.  A  problem  tree  analysis  is  in  Appendix  1  and  a  project  design  and 
monitoring framework is in Appendix 2. 
 
A. 
 
Uzbekistan  recorded  per  capita  gross  domestic  product  (GDP)  of  $814  in  2007.  GDP 
3. 
growth  rates  increased  from  3.8%  in  2000  to  4.4%  in  2003,  to  an  annual  average  of  over  7% 
during  2004–2006 2  and  9.5%  in  2007. 3  Agriculture  growth  fluctuated  from  3.2%  in  2000,  to 
10.1% in 2004 to 6.1% in 2007. The share of agriculture in GDP declined from 30.1% in 2000 to 
24.1%  in  2006.  Despite  this  decline,  agriculture  remains  an  important  sector,  accounting  for 
70%  of  domestic  trade,  35%–40%  of  industrial  output  (about  7.8%  of  GDP),  25%  of  export 
earnings,  and  33%  of  employment.  While  poverty  declined  from  27.5%  in  2001  to  25.8%  in 
2005,  poverty  in  rural  areas  remains  high.  About  64%  of  the  population  lives  in  rural  areas. 
Detailed analysis of the sector is provided in Appendix 3.  
 
4. 
Uzbekistan is an arid country. It relies on the Amu Darya and Syr Darya rivers and their 
tributaries to support irrigated agriculture. Water supply varies on a seasonal basis, with many 
areas  not  having  enough.  Irrigated  agriculture  accounts  for  over  90%  of  all  agricultural 
production  and  consumes  88%  of  all  water  resources—57  cubic  kilometers  annually.  The 
development  and  management  of  irrigation  and  drainage  infrastructure  and  improved  water 
management are fundamental actions to ensure that agriculture continues to develop over the 
medium term.  
 
5. 
Uzbekistan  has  about  4.3  million  hectares  (ha)  under  irrigation.  The  irrigation  network 
includes  inter-farm  and  on-farm  systems.4  Irrigation  primarily  relies  on  surface  water,  which  is 
distributed by gravity and pumps. The network includes (i) 30,000 kilometers (km) of main and 
inter-farm canals, with over 33,000 hydraulic structures; (ii) 1,500 pumping facilities, with almost 
5,000  pumps  that  supply  water  to  2  million  ha;  (iii)  175,000  km  of  on-farm  canals  and 
conveyance structures; (iv) 40,000 km of on-farm horizontal drains and 4,300 vertical drains; (v) 
120,000 km of drainage ditches; and (vi) 15,000 km of large drainage collectors.

The farming structure has evolved since independence. Shirkat farms were created from 
6. 
Soviet  collective  farms,  but  all  were  transformed  into  private  farms  by  the  end  of  2007.  There 
are now about 190,000 private farms with an average area of 26 ha. Shirkat farm operations are 
still  controlled  by  the  Government  through  the  quota  and  state  order  system,  especially  in  the 
case  of  the  strategic  commodities  of  cotton  and  wheat.  These  also  receive  credit  and  inputs 
from  the  Government.  Almost  1.8  million  people  are  employed  on  private  farms.  These  farms 
produce  32%  of  agricultural  output,  including  86%  of  raw  cotton  and  73%  of  grain  crops.  The 
state  order  system  has  been  relaxed  over  the  decade,  and  farms  can  now  sell  50%  of  their 
wheat and cotton production to the open market. This is having a good impact on productivity 
and  the  system  will  continue  to  be made  more  flexible.  Cotton  comprises  41%  of  the  irrigated 
area and wheat comprises 42%. The production system remains inefficient, and excess water 
use  contributes  to  salinity  and  land  degradation.  The  cropping  pattern  does  not  allow  for 
periodic  fallowing  of  land  or  rotation  with  fodder  or  other  crops  to  replenish  soil  nutrients  and 
absorb salts. Dekhan farms are small inheritable household plot (0.15–0.35 hectares) free from 
Government  quotas  for  crop  selection  and  marketing.  Their  land  use  rights  have  been 
transferred  to  private  individuals.  This  allows  for  secure  possession,  inheritance,  and  free 
cropping patterns. There are 4 million–5 million small dekhan farms. They produce nearly one 
fifth of the country’s grains and almost all of the horticulture output. They also provide important 
cash flow to farmers. 
 
Cotton  remains  the  priority  crop,  and  Uzbekistan  is  the  world’s  sixth  largest  producer. 
7. 
The  Government  plans  to  increase  the  domestic  use  of  cotton  fibers  and  raise  value  added 
through the development of a better textile industry. Wheat is the other priority crop, with self-
sufficiency achieved in 1997. Because of fluctuations in food prices and the current world food 
security situation, the Government intends to maintain its policy of wheat self-sufficiency.  
 
B. 
 
Irrigation  and  Drainage  Needs.  Although  the  infrastructure  was  well  built,  its  current 
8. 
condition  is  poor,  primarily  because  of  lack  of  investment  and  inadequate  maintenance. 
Government investment in agriculture as a whole has declined from 27% of all investments in 
1991  to  8%  in  2001.  From  1995  to  2002,  government  funding  for  the  water  network  dropped 
from 3% to under 2% of GDP. Expenditure in operation and maintenance (O&M) has slowed by 
one third. It is estimated that deferred capital and O&M expenditures amounts to 40% of asset 
value. 
 
The irrigation and drainage system needs substantial rehabilitation and upgrading (R&U) 
9. 
and  water  losses  are  high.  Some  structures  are  at  risk  of  total  failure,  which  would  cause 
agricultural  production  and  farm  incomes  to  decline  dramatically.  Investment  is  needed  in 
several areas: (i) total reconstruction of 32% of the main and inter-farm canals; (ii) repair of 24% 
of the main and inter-farm canal network; (iii) rebuilding of 42% of the on-farm irrigation network, 
and  repair  of  17%;  (iv)  replacement  and  modernization  of  mechanical  equipment  of  18  of  the 
42 large  intake  structures,  and  reconstruction  of  5;  (v)  16  of  the  27  inspected  reservoirs  are 
nonfunctional  or  threatened  with  sedimentation;  (vi)  19,000  km  of  on-farm  drainage  need  de-
silting,  and  11,500  km  of  open  and  subsurface  drains  need  reconstruction  or  repair;  and 
(vii) only 50% of the subsurface horizontal drainage systems are operational. The limited use of 
water-efficient irrigation technologies means an unneeded 10%–15% of water supply is required 
for irrigation. The high water table and use of drainage water for irrigation increases salinity and 
requires  substantial  water  for  leaching.  Sustained  investment  in  R&U  and  better  O&M  will 
prevent further deterioration and ensure stability in the farming system. 
 

Analysis of Key Problems and Opportunities 

  
 

Pumped irrigation and drainage is ubiquitous and poses special challenges. It includes 
10. 
the  three  massive  irrigation  pump  cascade  systems  from  the  Amu  Darya  (which  includes  the 
Amu  Bukhara,  Karshi,  and  Amu  Zhang  systems).  Together,  these  systems  irrigate  over 
800,000 ha of land. Amu Zhang is currently being rehabilitated under a project financed by ADB. 
The  other  two  large  cascades  also  need  urgent  rehabilitation.5  Smaller  pump-based  irrigation 
facilities  are  located  throughout  the  gravity  irrigation  networks,  with  schemes  of  10,000  ha  of 
farmland commonly reliant on pumps. Almost all pumps are operating beyond their design life, 
and their maintenance and repair has been poor. Pumps are starting to fail or threatening to do 
so.  Of  the  76  very  large  pumping  facilities  with  capacities  greater  than  100  cubic  meters  per 
second  (m3/sec),  60  require  immediate  rehabilitation.  In  addition,  400  of  the  1,000  smaller 
pumped  systems,  with  capacities  less  than  10  m3/sec,  need  immediate  rehabilitation  or 
replacement.  Pumped  irrigation  absorbs  70%  of  the  annual  O&M  budget  of  the  Ministry  of 
Agriculture and Water Resources (MAWR). It consumes 20% of Uzbekistan’s electricity, and the 
outdated equipment consumes 20%–25% more electricity than modern equipment. Substantial 
investment is needed to convert the pumped system into efficient and cost-effective operations. 
The  efficiency  of  smaller  pumped  systems  can  be  improved  through  new  technology,  more 
demand-responsive operating regimes, and improved irrigation techniques. 
 
11. 
The  total  land  area  of  the  country  is  18  million  ha,  of  which  25%  is  arable  land  and 
largely  irrigated.  The  degraded  state  of  irrigation  and  drainage  infrastructure,  combined  with 
poor water management, result in low water use efficiency and agricultural productivity. Average 
water withdrawal for irrigation is 14,000 cubic meters (m3) per ha, compared with 9,000 m3 per 
ha to 10,000 m3 per ha in countries with similar climates. Irrigation efficiency nationwide is only 
about 40% resulting in wasted water, overloaded drainage systems, environmental degradation, 
and worsening land salinization. MAWR estimates that more than 20,000 ha of land goes out of 
production each year because of salinity. The salinity affects cotton yields, which decline 20%–
30%  on  slightly  salinized  land,  but  up  to  80%  on  highly  salinized  land.  Some  degree  of 
salinization and waterlogging affects 47% of all irrigated land. Productivity in irrigated agriculture 
dropped by 15% in the immediate post-Soviet era. Although recovering slowly, much more work 
is  required  to  improve  agricultural  productivity.  Yields  are  low  at  2.25  tons  per  ha  (t/ha)  in  the 
case of cotton and 4.2 t/ha for wheat.  
 
Institutional Framework and Management of Irrigation and Drainage. The legal and 
12. 
regulatory  framework  for  irrigation  and  drainage  is  derived  from  the  Law  on  Water  and  Water 
Use, 1993. This addresses water rights and allocation, O&M of irrigation and drainage systems, 
and  resolution  of  water  disputes.  Other  decrees  and  laws  support  the  establishment  of  the 
institutions  responsible  for  water  resources  and  irrigation  and  drainage.  A  generally  sound 
framework for water management and irrigation is in place, but additional supporting legislation

Narpay  Core  Subproject.  The  Narpay  pump  system  is  located  in  Narpay  District  in 
northwest  Samarkand  Province.  The  area  has  a  continental  climate  with  an  average  annual 
temperature  of  15°  centigrade  and  low  rainfall  (271  millimeters  [mm]),  most  of  which  occurs 
during winter. The command area (8,206 ha) has sierozems (gray desert soils) characterized by 
low organic content with moderate productivity potential. The average farm size is about 27 ha; 
cotton (57%) and wheat (30%) are the main crops and fodder vegetables, melons, and orchard 
and  vineyards  are  grown  on  a  smaller  scale.  The  pumping  plant  and irrigation system  receive 
water from the Narpay primary canal, fed by the Zarafshan River. They were established in the 
early 1970s and have undergone subsequent modification, including the addition of secondary 
pumps  with  new  irrigated  area.  The  primary  pumping  plant  has  only  six  of  eight  pumps 
operational and their capacity is only about 75% of their design. This situation—coupled with the 
unreliability  of  the  six  remaining  pumps—results  in  frequent  partial  shutdowns  and  seriously 
limits the water available for irrigation, particularly during peak demand for the cotton crop. The 
inter-farm canal system, which distributes water from the pumps, is in fair condition, yet portions 
exist  where  repair  and/or  replacement  of  the  concrete  lining  is  required;  existing  control 
structures  need  repair  and/or  replacement;  and  a  number  of  additional  control  and 
measurement structures are required. The reduced and unreliable pumping plant output, along 
with efficiency constraints of the distribution network, result in cotton yields considerably below 
the average for the whole of Narpay District. In the absence of urgent R&U, the productivity of 
the Narpay system will continue to decline and is in danger of partial or total collapse.

Besharyk District of Fergana Province between the Syr Darya River to the north and Besharyk

perennial  fodder  crops.  The  pumping  plant  takes  water  directly  from  the  Syr  Darya  River  and 
was established in 1978. Both the capacity and the level of reliability have declined significantly. 
The plant was designed with 10 pumps, eight for irrigation and two to supply water to extensive 
fishponds  in  the  area.  During  the  past  seven  seasons,  only  four  pumps  have  been  operating

system, and the drainage network all require considerable R&U to prevent the possible partial or 
total collapse of the system. The inter-farm distribution network also needs to be expanded and 
rationalized to capture the full benefits associated with the production potential of the area.

2. 
Water  Resources,  Irrigation,  and  Drainage.  Uzbekistan  is  an  arid  country  and  has 
average rainfall of 264 millimeters (mm), from a low 97 mm in the northwest to 425 mm in the 
mountainous areas. The country lies fully within the Amu Darya river basin that covers 86.5% of 
the  land,  and  the  Syr  Darya  river  basin  that  covers  13.5%  of  the  land.  These  rivers  and  their 
tributaries  provide  all  the  water  resources  to  support  irrigated  agriculture.  However,  the  water 
they  supply  varies  considerably  on  a  seasonal  basis  and  with  regard  to  the  location  in  the 
country, with many areas suffering extreme water scarcity. Because of Uzbekistan’s arid climate 
and  the  variability  in  availability  of  water  resources,  almost  all  agriculture  has  always  been 
dependent  on  irrigation.  Irrigation  takes  place  on  90%  of  the  farmed  arable  land  and  is 
responsible  for  nearly  all  agricultural  production.  It  consumes  85%  of  all  water  resources  and 
requires about 57 cubic kilometers (km3) annually. Accordingly, development and management 
of irrigation and drainage infrastructure and  improved water management are key government 
priorities. 
 
 Uzbekistan  has  4.3  million  hectares  (ha)  of  irrigated  land  (2.35  million  ha  in  the  Amu

irrigation  in  Central  Asia,  and  nearly  double  that  of  Kazakhstan,  which  ranks  next  in  terms  of 
irrigated area. In 1960, Uzbekistan had less than 2.6 million ha, yet by 1990, the Soviet Union 
had expanded irrigation to its current area. This was mainly for intensive cotton production. The 
rapid development of intensive irrigated agriculture throughout Central Asia during this period is 
largely responsible for desiccation of the Aral Sea and the associated environmental, social, and 
economic disaster. However, the massive investment economically transformed many areas in 
Uzbekistan  and  improved  the  livelihoods  of  rural  communities  who  are  now  completely 
dependent on the flow of irrigation water.

inter-farm system comprises the large intake structures for water irrigation supply, and the main 
and distributary canals that convey water to the farm level outlets as well as the large collector

5. 
Agriculture and Farming Systems. Cotton is the priority crop grown, and Uzbekistan is 
the world’s sixth largest producer. Cotton received extensive and intensive development under 
the Soviet Union. Since Uzbekistan’s independence in 1992, wheat self-sufficiency also became 
a  strategic  priority  of  the  Government,  and  it  was  first  achieved  in  1997.  Wheat  and  cotton 
comprise  the  vast  majority  of  agricultural  production,  with  cotton  grown  on  about  41%  of  the 
irrigated area and wheat on 42% of the irrigated area. 
 
6. 
Irrigated farm production is based on three types of farms: (i) shirkat farms, which were 
created  from  Soviet  collective  farms;  (ii)  private  farms;  and  (iii)  dekhan  (small  inheritable 
household  plot  [0.15–0.35  hectares]  free  from  Government  quotas  for  crop  selection  and 
marketing)  farms.  The  shirkats  were  formed  during  the  1990s  as  a  reform  of  the  former  state 
farms, but their operation was still based on collective ownership of the farm assets, and their 
performance  was  poor.  As  a  remedy,  the  Government  increased  efforts  to  “privatize”  the 
shirkats by breaking them into smaller parcels and selling them for management and operation 
by individuals. By 2004, 125,000 private farms had been established on over 2.3 million ha, and 
today all of the shirkats have been eliminated and converted to private farms.  
 
7. 
While many of the shirkats have been privatized to individuals, is the private farms are 
still  controlled  by  the  Government,  which  dictates  the  production  and  marketing  of  cotton  and 
wheat. Farmers are subject to quotas to grow large areas of cotton and wheat with subsidized 
credits  and  inputs.  They  are  also  required  to  sell  50%  of  the  wheat  and  cotton  harvest  to  the 
Government  below  world  market  prices.  The  Government  controls  a  significant  portion  of  the 
value  chain  for  these  crops.  The  production  quotas  tied  to  cotton  and  wheat  also  require 
intensive  water  use  and  contribute  to  salinization  and  land  degradation.  In  addition,  land  use 
contracts are often not registered or recognized, so local authorities can evict farmers who do 
not  meet  production  quotas,  and  the  title  of  the  land  is  not  transferable  to  another  user.  This 
situation limits  incentives  for  private  productivity  investments  and  limits  credit  availability  since 
farms  are  not  viable  collateral.  The  wheat  and  cotton  cropping  rotation  does  not  allow  for 
periodic  fallowing  of  land  or  rotation  with  fodder  or  other  crops  to  replenish  soil  nutrients  and 
absorb salts. Dekhan farms are generally quite small fringe holdings, and  their  land  rights  are 
clearly  established  to  private  individuals,  which  allow  secure  long-term  possession  and  free 
cropping  patterns.  There  are  about  4  million–5  million  of  these  small  dekhan  farms,  and  they 
produce  nearly  one-fifth  of  the  country’s  grains,  nearly  all  of  the  horticulture,  and  provide 
important cash income for farmers.

8. 
Irrigation  and  Drainage  Needs.  During  the  time  of  the  former  Soviet  Union,  new 
infrastructure  was  constructed  and  existing  infrastructure  improved,  but  its  condition  has 
deteriorated since independence. The state’s share in agricultural investment has declined, from 
27%  in  1991  to  8%  in  2001.  From  1995  to  2002,  government  funding  for  the  water  sector 
dropped from 2.9% to 1.8% of GDP—a 60% decrease. At the same time, resources for capital 
investment in the water sector declined from 0.9% to 0.6% of GDP, reducing funds for operation 
and  maintenance  (O&M)  by  a  third.  Currently,  it  is  estimated  that  deferred  capital  and  O&M 
expenditures are about 40% of the irrigation and drainage asset value. 
 
9. 
The  irrigation  and  drainage  system  needs  substantial  rehabilitation  and  upgrading 
(R&U), and major irrigation structures are at risk of failure that would cause significant losses in 
agricultural production. The following R&U needs have been identified throughout the country (i) 
total  reconstruction  of  32%  of  the  main  and  inter-farm  canals,  and  repair  of  24%  of  them;  (ii) 
rebuilding  of  42%  of  the  on-farm  irrigation  network,  and  repairs  for  17%;  (iii)  replacement  and 
modernization of the mechanical equipment of 18 of the 42 large-intake structures (about 10–
300  cubic  meters  per  second  [m3/sec])  and  reconstruction  of  5;  (iv)  16  of  the  27  inspected 
reservoirs are nonfunctional or threatened with sedimentation; (v) 19,000 km of on-farm drains 
need  de-silting,  and  11,500  km  of  open  and  subsurface  drains  need  reconstruction  or  repair; 
and  (vi)  only  about  50%  of  the  subsurface  horizontal  drainage  systems  are  operational.  To 
rectify this situation will require sustained R&U investment into the system, and new modalities 
for O&M are required to prevent further deterioration and to ensure that investment returns are 
sustainable following system R&U. 
 
10. 
Pumped  irrigation  provides  water  to  about  half  the  irrigated  area  in  Uzbekistan  and 
poses unique challenges. It includes the three massive irrigation pump cascades systems from 
the Amu Darya River that include the Amu Bukhara, Karshi, and Amu Zhang systems. Together, 
the  systems  irrigate  over  800,000  ha  of  land,  and  entire  regions  with  numerous  towns  and 
villages  and  millions  of  people  are  dependent  on  their  continued  operation.  Amu  Zhang  is 
currently  being  rehabilitated  through  ADB  support  although  the  other  two  large  cascades  also 
need  urgent  rehabilitation. 3  Other  smaller  yet  still  substantial  pumped  irrigation  facilities  are 
located throughout all the gravity irrigation networks, with schemes in the range of 5,000–10,000 
ha  reliant  on  pumps  being  quite  common.  Almost  all  irrigation  and  drainage  pumps  in 
Uzbekistan are operating beyond their design life and adequate resources have been lacking for 
their  maintenance  since  independence.  Many  pumps  are  starting  to  fail,  and  without 
intervention,  many  more  are  likely  to  fail  soon.  Of  the  76  very  large  pumping  facilities  with 
capacities greater than 100 m3/sec, 60 require immediate rehabilitation. In addition, 400 of the 
1,000  smaller  pumped  systems,  with  capacities  of  10  m3/sec  or  less  need  immediate 
rehabilitation or replacement. Energy for pumped irrigation accounts for 70% of the annual O&M 
budget  of  the  Ministry  of  Agriculture  and  Water  Resources  (MAWR),  and  consumes  20%  of 
Uzbekistan’s electricity. Substantial investment is needed for R&U of the pumped systems since 
their failure would eliminate a significant portion of irrigated areas and substantially reduce the 
livelihoods of rural communities farming in these systems. Opportunities also exist to increase 
the  efficiency  of  smaller  pumped  extension  systems  through  new  pump  technology,  more 
demand-responsive operating regimes, and improved irrigation techniques.

18.  Water  Users’  Associations.  With  the  conversion  of  the  shirkats  to  private  farms,  the 
former  state-supported  O&M  and  management  of  the  on-farm  irrigation  and  drainage

limits,  maintain  infrastructure,  take  measures  to  reduce  land  salinization,  observe  sustainable 
crop  rotations,  adopt  water-saving  technologies,  and  endeavor  to  increase  water  productivity. 
WUAs  are  forbidden  to  operate  inter-farm  infrastructure  for  the  purpose  of  increasing  or 
decreasing  water  supply.  The  experience  with  WUAs  in  Uzbekistan  is  limited  and  variable. 
Although they have been established in most cases, there is no institutionalized program within 
MAWR that provides for their training or resources to support their establishment, and they have 
developed under various models. They also lack equipment since much of the equipment that 
was supposed to be transferred to them from the shirkats was sold off prior to transfer or is not 
functional. WUA sizes vary, with some entire districts put under one WUA. Responsibilities also 
vary  depending  on  the  type  and  complexity  of  system  that  has  been  transferred.  Financial 
sustainability is also difficult since WUA membership fees, along with the rate of collection from 
farmers.  The  WUAs  also  have  limited  options  in  their  ability  to  collect  payment.  The  Swiss 
Agency  for  Development  and  Cooperation  (SDC)  has  provided  training  and  support  for  some 
WUAs. This has significantly improved their performance with regard to water management and 
system O&M, and provides experience from which to scale up a broader training effort. WUAs 
play a vital role in improving the productivity of irrigated agriculture and water management, yet 
they require greater support to fulfill this mandate more effectively. 
 
19.  Water  Management. Given the importance of irrigation and the reliance of Uzbekistan 
on water coming across its borders, effective water management is essential within the country. 
Improving  the  technical  competence  of  the  BISAs,  MCAs,  and  ISAs  can  improve  water  use 
efficiency  and  productivity.  Capacity  building  for  water  management  should  complement  any 
inter-farm  investment  in  infrastructure  to  help  realize  its  full  potential.  The  inter-farm  irrigation 
system  would  also  benefit  from  improved  water  monitoring,  measurement,  and  more  effective 
management. Potential exists to improve water use efficiency by upgrading existing structures 
and controls through new operational procedures, automation, and supervisory control and data 
acquisition  systems.  MAWR  has  already  seen  positive  benefits  from  limited  use  of  these 
measures in the Fergana Valley and in the Zarafshan river basin under programs by the United 
States  Agency  for  International  Development  and  SDC.  More  comprehensive  application  of 
these  technologies,  with  associated  training  for  BISAs,  can  further  improve  water  use 
efficiencies.  
 
20. 
Efficiency  gains  can  be  achieved  through  better  planning  and  integration  of  ISA  staff 
operating  the  inter-farm  canals  and  structures,  and  WUA  staff  operating  on-farm  canals,  to 
optimize water deliveries. Especially in the pump systems, which have greater flexibility and can 
be  more  demand-responsive,  better  communication  and coordination  between  WUAs  and  ISA 
staff  could  yield  substantial  benefits.  As  noted,  on-farm  water  management  is  under  the 
supervision of the WUAs, which need capacity development for improved water management. 
In  cases  where  training  has  been  provided  combined  with  measurement  structures  in  the  on-
farm canals, savings of 10%–20% have been realized along with productivity improvements. All 
levels of irrigation in Uzbekistan can be made more efficient with improved water management.

water resources management, and (iii) project management.  
 
The  Government  of  Uzbekistan’s  Welfare  Improvement  Strategy  2008–2010  commits  to  pursuing  the  Millennium 
Development Goals relevant to the country. It identifies four pillars for reducing poverty in Uzbekistan: (i) high growth 
rates  by  maintaining  macroeconomic  stability  and  accelerating  structural  reforms,  (ii)  human  development  and  social 
protection,  (iii)  reduced  interregional  inequalities  in  living  standards,  and  (iv)  improved  environmental  protection.  The 
strategy emphasizes that further reforms in agriculture and implementation of an agricultural development program are 
the long-term strategic priorities since they will lead to improvement in incomes for a significant part of the population 
who live in rural areas and have low-income employment.b   

Under  ADB’s  country  strategy  and  program  for  2006–2010  in  Uzbekistan,  strategic  priority  1  is  accelerated 
environmentally  sustainable  rural  development  with  the  following  long-term  country  outcomes:  (i)  agricultural 
productivity  and  farm  profitability  improved  in  a  sustainable  manner,  (ii)  rural  non-farm  employment  productivity 
increased,  and  (iii)  access  to  and  efficiency  of  rural  infrastructure  increased.  The  Project  is  included  under  strategic 
priority 1 of the country strategy and program.c  

In 2007, 25.8% of the people in Uzbekistan were living below the poverty line with one third of the poor or 2.3 million 
people classified extremely poor. About 70% of the poor live in rural areas. In 2001, the poverty rate in rural areas was 
30.5%, compared to 22.5% in urban areas. It declined in 2002 to 27.8%, but rose slightly in 2003 to 29%. The overall 
poverty rate dropped to 26.1% in 2004, and 25.8% in 2007.

SOCIAL ANALYSIS AND STRATEGY 

A.  Findings of Social Analysis  
 
A  socioeconomic  survey  was  undertaken  in  both  the  Narpay  and  Besharyk  subproject  areas  under  the  PPTA.  The 
population in the settlements within the Narpay subproject in Narpay district, Samarkand Province is 13,663 persons or 
2,973  families.  In  the  Besharyk  subproject,  located  in  Fergana  province,  the  population  is  32,333  persons  or  8,673 
families.  The  average  household  size  for  the  surveyed  households  is  5.32  people  in  Narpay  and  6.0  people  in 
Besharyk. 
According  to  the  World  Bank  study,e  based  on  the  household  budget  survey  data  in  the  Northern  Economic  Region, 
which includes Samarkand Province, 28.3% of the population was living below the poverty line; in Fergana Province, 
the figure was 31.8%. In 2005, based on the household budget survey conducted by the State Committee on Statistics 
of the Republic of Uzbekistan, the World Bank identified that the poverty rate was 23.9% in Samarkand Province and 
15.8% in Fergana. At the same time, the average poverty rate for the whole country was 25.8% (footnote b). 
The  socioeconomic  survey  showed  a  household  poverty  rate  of  30.5%  in  Narpay  subproject  area  and  19.5%  in  the 
Besharyk  subproject  area,  equivalent  to  a  total  of  46,000  people  in  the  two  subproject  areas.  The  poverty  line  in 
monetary terms is $26.7 per month in the Narpay subproject district and $25.0 per month in the Besharyk subproject 
district. The average monthly household income is $126 for Narpay and $254 in Besharyk. Average family per capita 
income of the poor is nearly 2 times lower than the income of the nonpoor. 
Income from hired employment in the nonagricultural sector is the most significant for poor families. The second most 
important income sources are social transfers and marketing of own agricultural products. The contribution of pensions 
and social transfers to total income among poor families (including social benefits for low-income households) is 21% in 
Narpay district and 16.3% in Besharyk district.   

The  share  of  the  unemployed  is  higher  in  poor  families  (37%  more  in  poor  families)  and  more  than  67%  of  the 
unemployed  are  women.  Most  of  the  poor  are  hired  workers,  employed  in  the  agricultural  or  state-budget-funded 
sectors, or self-employed people who cultivate their own small household plots (up to 0.1 ha). 

 
The general level of education of the population in the project area is high (similar to the country in general), but the 
share  of  adults  in  the  employable  age  and  above,  who  have  vocational  education  (particularly  higher  education)  is 
comparatively  small,  which  is  typical  for  rural  areas.  Education  indicators  are  a  little  lower  in  poor  families  than  in 
nonpoor families.  

More than 2.5% of the population has become private farmers, and primarily employs only family members as private 
farm workers. Self-employment opportunities are limited because of the shortage of resources, underdeveloped market 
institutions,  legislative  limitations,  and  lack  of  information  about  ways  and  opportunities  of  increasing  income  in  new 
market-oriented conditions.

Electricity  supply  is  relatively  good,  compared  to  other  rural  areas  of  the  country:  98%  of  households  in  Narpay  and

Open reservoirs (mainly the Narpay machine canal) represent the main source of potable water—about 75% of survey

people in the project areas drink and cook with water that falls short of current sanitary standards. Children, who drink 
water from various sources without any treatment, are particularly vulnerable. 

Poor living standards of households within the subproject areas are also due to low productivity in household plots and 
low incomes from agriculture. The average per capita income of poor households is 1.4 times less than the nonpoor 
households  and  1.3  times  lower  than  that  of  the  average  households.  The  same  rates  were  observed  in  terms  of

validation of LARP implementation activities. 
 
8. 
The PMO will also solicit the assistance from the government administration of provinces 
and districts and the SCLRGCSC subdivisions at the province and district levels as well as the 
concerned  parties.  The  concerned  parties  will  be  composed  of  representatives  of  farmers, 
owners  of  dekhan  farms  and  the  neighboring  landowners  and  users,  including  the  affected 
persons.  They  will  serve  as  witness  to  the  marking  of  lands  and  jointly  issue  the  certificate  of 
land  markings  to  PMO.  The  certificate  will  be  included  as  part  of  the  preparation  of  the 
instruction  on  land  allocation.  Table  A12.2  summarizes  the  phasing  of  the  involvement  of 
concerned  project  personnel  and  institutions  in  LARP  preparation  and  implementation.  All  the 
concerned staff of PMO, MAWR, and the local nongovernment organization  involved in LARP 
activities will undergo an orientation and training on ADB resettlement policy and management. 
The  orientation  and  training  will  be  conducted  by  the  resettlement  specialist  (technical 
assistance consultant). 
 
F. 
 
9. 
Funds  will  be  provided  for  all  LARPs.  Provisions  will  cover  the  compensation, 
assistance,  other  allowances  to  affected  persons,  implementing  costs,  and  contingency 
allowance  for  unforeseen  expenses  and  for  cushioning  the  effect  of  inflation.  MAWR  will 
approve the budgets and facilitate the release of funds for implementing the LARP. The LARPs 
will describe the flow of funds including the accounting systems, as these are part of the overall 
project  development  expenditures  for  which  ADB,  through  the  external  monitoring  agent,  will 
monitor the disbursements for LARPs. 
 
G. 
 
10. 
Internal  and  external  monitoring  will  be  conducted  during  LARP  implementation.  The 
PMO,  assisted  by  the  local  NGO  and  resettlement  specialist,  will  be  responsible  for  internal 
monitoring.  Internal  monitoring  will  cover  activities  related  to  (i)  information  campaigns  and 
consultation  with  affected  persons;  (ii)  status  of  land  acquisition  and  payments  on  land 
compensation;  (iii)  compensation  for  affected  structures  and  other  assets;  (iv)  relocation  of 
affected persons; (v) payments for loss of incomes; (vi) selection and distribution of replacement 
land areas; and (vii) income restoration activities. Related information will be collected from the 
field  and  reported  monthly  to  the  PMO  to  assess  the  progress  and  results  of  LARP 
implementation,  and  to  adjust  the  work  program,  if  necessary.  The  monthly  reports  will  be 
consolidated every quarter and be a part of quarterly reporting by the PMO to ADB. 
 
11.
